title: 109_s786
content: The Act titled "National Weather Services Duties Act of 2005" outlines the duties and responsibilities of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Weather Service. The National Weather Service, under the Secretary of Commerce, is responsible for issuing severe weather forecasts and warnings, providing hydrometeorological guidance, collecting and exchanging weather data, and offering reports and advice to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Commerce shall not provide products or services that can be offered by the private sector unless the private sector is unable or unwilling to do so, or if the US Government is obligated under international agreements. Data, forecasts, and warnings from NOAA and the National Weather Service must be shared to the maximum extent. The National Weather Service must issue data, information, guidance, forecasts, and warnings in real time to ensure equal public access. This information should be accessible through data portals for commercial providers and other mechanisms as deemed appropriate by the Secretary of Commerce. Additionally, there are prohibitions on certain disclosures by officers, employees, or agents of NOAA and other related agencies. The National Weather Service and related agencies are prohibited from sharing weather data that could impact market value before or after public issuance. The Secretary of Commerce will prescribe regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment to implement the provisions regarding the definition of "product or service" as related to meteorological data. The effective date of these provisions, excluding subsection (e), will be 90 days after the Act's enactment. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to the Act of October 1, 1890, including the repeal of Section 3 and amendments to Section 9. Section 9 (15 U.S.C. 317) is amended by striking ``, and it shall be'' and all that follows and inserting a period. SEC. 3. REPORT ON MODIFICATION OF NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION AND NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE ACTIVITIES. The Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of this Act, detailing any activities of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Weather Service that do not align with the provisions of section 2, along with a schedule for modifying these activities to comply with the law. The report must also include the regulations outlined in section 2(e). The term "appropriate committees of Congress" refers to the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, and the House Committee on Science.
